Review Text: My wife & I went to the Christmas Morning service which was magical We were the only Europeans at the service, but it was all in English language I have no idea as to what their normal audiences are, but on Christmas morning  it was packed with a congregation of about 50 It is a lovely church

Review Title: Beautiful church in a gorgeous setting
Review Text: It's a beautiful church built in 1819.  My mom, as a child attended this church 69 years ago and we brought her back after 69 years for her to experience her childhood church
Nestled in between various tea plantations, our driver brought to our attention this former British church while leaving the winding road back to Hatton. A very serene church indeed.

Truly magical place with it serenity and sense of silence blending in to the incredibly beautiful location where this little church is placed. Be aware all the time of the fact its cemetery as well where a careful look at the tomb stones would reveal the deaths of many young souls at the prime of their age- succumbed to disease it's said, when the mountains took a heavy toll on the a pioneers irrespective of the position. Photography  is not allowed so its best to abide by the polite caretaker.What awaits a traveler once inside the church is beyond description so better to feel it first hand .Caretaker is well versed in the matters related to the church. A little donation box by the entrance, so a little help in keeping this serendipitous place the way it stands would be the duty of a visitor.

Review Title: Ones if the oldest pipe organs
Review Text: This is an very old church belonging to England congregation. It's beautiful designed and they have one of the Oldest pipe organs

One of the best memories of British colonial life time and antique furniture and pipe organ with old bible glass painting are more colorful and unique best place to visit when you travel Hatton Surrounding tea plantations and great view of Casgtregh reservoir behind the church must visit highly Recommended

Review Title: Ancient British Church of historical importance
Review Text: Our group of seventeen travelling together as a group visited the Walreigh Church at Dickoya along Hatton - Norwood Road in the morning on 27th March 2021.  Our group leader, Padmini, had pre-arranged and obtained permission to enter the compound and to be shown around this quaint little church. This Church built by the British in 1878 is one of the oldest and prominent Anglican churches in Sri Lanka.  It had been built with granite stone blocks now looking ash coloured.  The Church is scenically located surrounded by tea estates and borders the Castlereigh lake.  The caretaker and sexton Mr Felix Coulton welcomed us, took us in and described its history.  Many tombstones of British Planters lie at the cemetery surrounding the church. A bible printed around 1865 and presented to the church in 1879 occupies the pride of place near the pulpit.  The stained-glass windows, with Jesus paintings, are attractive and livens the church interior.  An old ancient church organ adorns the entrance.  Wooden church benches and the pulpit too appear ancient.  Floral tiles, imported from England, are laid out on the floor. We greatly enjoyed the visit to this church located in picture-postcard surrounds.  Here, I felt a feeling of nostalgia of what it would have been!

Review Title: Worth to visit if you go to Hatton
Review Text: This small place is situated at side of Hatton-Dick Oya road. History of Anglican church goes back to 19th century but they maintain the same condition. There is a care taker to show inside of the church. The pipe organ (still function) and holy Bible (printed in 1860) are two special things can be seen inside the church. They don't allow photographs inside the church after Easter attack.  The churchyard is full of tombs of people of colonial era. You can see the tomb of first British Inspector General of Police at the entrance of the church.

Paid a whistle stop visit here and what a beautiful little church it is. Sad to see the cemetery with such young people buried there over the years. Predominantly tea planters. The church is maintained to impeccable standards. The stained glass windows were shipped from the uk. There’s a miniature wind piano that’s 99years old with a larger piped organ to the rear. Well worth a quick tour.
My great uncle is buried here, he died at 21 months old in 1898.  It was a powerful experience to visit here and is a beautiful little church in an idyllic setting.

This was an accidental find. But what a treasure ! This tiny church is packed with history related to us by an enthusiastic caretaker. If you do travel around DIckoya area, please do  visit this delightful church.

Christ Church. Walreigh, Dickoya, Sri Lanka Built in 1878, this Anglican church is packed with a valuable history. The Bible  has been presented in 1879 and the stained glass murals are beautiful. It has a pipe organ as well. The gardens are well maintained and the scenic location on the Hatton - Norton road is admirable.

Christ Church. Walreigh, Dickoya, Sri Lanka Built in 1878, this Anglican church is packed with a valuable history. The Bible  has been presented in 1879 and the stained glass murals are beautiful. It has a pipe organ as well. The gardens are well maintained and the scenic location on the Hatton - Norton road is admirable.

We stayed in Dickoya for a few days and the owner suggested us to visit this nice church but to our surprise, they do not allow visitors in. We asked the guy who takes care of the church when we could visit the place and he told us that it was closed to tourists after the bombings that took place in May so no way to get inside.
This place is a definite must see. It was so beautiful and so haunting in the most tranquil way. I can’t believe Sri Lanka has such magnificent places.
lovely stain glass, pipe organ, antique furniture, serene and beautiful, located in a very scenic place, caretaker very helpful , opens the well kept church if required,
Well we came from Hatton to Adams peak, it's on the road, we stoped for 15 min, it's nice to see such old church...
this is a historical church & one of very few attractions in  Dikoya.  its open from 9 am to 5 PM & there is a Person who will explain  the whole story of the church.
The church is one of the few near by attractions of the area. The inside of the church is beautiful. The outside ground is burial ground of many British families.

Built in 1878 according to old British architecture  the Christ Church Warleigh was a gift from William Scott. Sitting by the Hatton Nortan Road just two km from Dickoya town the church is still maintained to its past glory. The gardens of Christ Church Warleigh rest some of the first planters settled down in Sri Lanka. Take your camera you could bring back some interesting memories. The the first Bible gifted to the chuch,antique furniture, old Piano are all  preserved to date.

Stepping into the church was like stepping into my local parish church back home. The stained glass windows are spectacular & worth a visit for them alone. The Vicar was there with some local people cleaning the church which was very inspiring to see their care of the building The Vicar sadly told me he has the same issues as back home, a dwindling congregation & lack of funds to maintain the Church building. The roof clearly had a large hole in it. I wish the congregation well & hope it is still there in another 140 years (it was built in 1878)
one of good place in srilanka nice place with green colour ,dutch church ,adamespeak its really good to visit

The church built in typical old British church architecture is quite quaint. One can see the original bible that was gifted to the church. It is a quick 15 minute journey by car from the Governor’s Mansion.

We enjoyed visiting this small, gorgeous church overlooking the Castlereigh Reservoir.  It has been very well maintained. The stained glass windows are original and it has two functioning organs. It isn't open to visitors everyday of the week, so it is worth finding out which day it is before visiting.  Good to combine with a tour of the reservoir.

This is a beautiful small church built in colonial time overlooking the Castlereagh reservoir. The first bible which was brought down to Sri Lanka is on display inside the church. Original piano and the pipe organ are still working and services are still held. Churchyard has quite a number of gravestones of people died from 1800 s to recent times. Caretaker will provide visitors with all historic information. Pictures can be taken even inside the church. But, videos are not allowed. The area is quite scenic. If your are in Dikoya, this is a must visit.

We were lucky and a very well informed member of the local congragation was there and invited us to give us a little tour. He knew all the facts the founding of this church. We went also inside and could take pictures. Many thanks again.

It's a wonderful and old (built in 1878) Christ Church situated in Dickoya, near to Castlereagh Reservoir. The passionate caretaker, Mr. Felix will tell you stories of the Church and gravestones for hours if you show the interest. Inside the church, there is one big horn pipe organ and according to Mr. Felix, it's one of the five pipe organs in Sri Lanka. We heard that people from almost all the religions come here to pay their respect, and if you are to visit the Church, kindly keep in mind that this is a resting place for  50+ people died from 1800s to nowadays.
small historical church worth a visit.  Services held up to date in this century old church.  A must visit when in Dickoya

A really beautiful Church built in 1879 which is beautifully kept by a very knowledgeable caretaker. It could have come straight out of the Lake District in the UK with its stunning views. The caretaker's wife was buried there too and he is pleased that she has the very best view.
Absolutely beautiful location and view.  Really friendly and passionate caretaker of the church who tells the story and show you arround.

A picture-book Church in a Picture book setting.  Located over the beautiful Castlereigh reservoir, the Church has a 150 year old Bible and beautiful stained glass windows.  It is a Parish Church and also has the Cemetary/Churchyard of the traditional Anglican Churches.  It is not open all the time, but if you ask Felix, the curator,  is very helpful and knowledgeable.

We walked to this church from Dickoya along the road and enjoyed the walk as it passes temples, tea plantations, locals going about their business etc. The church was opened for us by a young boy and the cemetery outside is still in use and beautifully preserved - interesting gravestones. It overlooks a huge reservoir which is very scenic and we walked down to the Tamil village below the church and were made very welcome by kids and villagers.

We visited this church and it was like being in a small village anywhere in England (except it was much warmer!). It is an amazingly preserved church perched on a hill overlooking the reservoir.  You only need 15 minutes or so to look round and can do it on the way to somewhere else such as a tea factory tour.  Look at the gravestones outside as well as they all help tell the story of this little piece of preserved England in Sri Lanka.
Very beautiful place  with a amazing view. It's very nice for a short visit and it's ob the way from Hatton-Dickoya to Adam's Peak. The gardner was very friendly.
A nice place to visit when in the region dating back to history Sarounded by the waters of Castlereagh, afeast for the eyes !

Built in 1800s one of the beautiful Anglican Church with nice ancient architecture with old antique furniture, pianos and Gothic style art is something you can witness here. Located on the edge of the Castlereagh Reservoir and in the middle of a tea estate - the setting is beautiful and worth visiting. Few minutes from Clovefield Villa (about 35 minutes) and worth visiting this beautiful place.

This area in Sri Lanka is so very picturesque and beautiful.  You will be amazed at the tranquill hills covered by tea plantations and the amazing clean fresh air all around.  We were very fortunate to have stayed at Dickoya while on holiday in Sri Lanka.  We will definitely be back here soon.

Visited here whilst staying in the area, this has a peaceful setting with a wonderful view down over the reservoir. The church has many English links with an interesting graveyard. The caretaker and son opened the church for us to view inside and were at pains to help and inform us of the history especially once they found out that my wife's ancestors once lived in the area
Visit and see the wonders internal and external of this Church from the 1880's......the view at the rear of the church across the lake is superb.
This church has been built in 1878. It is well maintained. The brass plates were shinning and the floor was well polished. The garden was well maintained.
I was there for a while on Sunday church prayer when visiting the lake view. It's a very historical and beautiful church, worth for a short visit if you have time.

This little church was built in 1878 and is located in the midst of Sri Lanka's tea plantations in the central hills, near the little town of Dickoya. It is a very peaceful setting with fabulous views over the waters of Castlereigh Reservoir. The church has lovely stained glass windows, carved wood alter and pulpit as well as a very old organ that is still in use. This beautiful church has a special place in my heart because my great grandfather is buried there. Robert Calhoun Grant was from Scotland, became a tea planter in Sri Lanka and probably went to Warleigh Church most Sundays. He died in January 1915 and is among many other British people in that churchyard who have contributed to the growth of Ceylon Tea!

This little church was built in 1878 and is still in use today. It is in immaculate condition. Outside there is a graveyard with many many graves of Britsh people, planters ,civil servants etc who lived here during British Rule, many of whom died very young. It is a most interesting place and well worth a visit.

We came across this church by chance during our walk from the Upper Glencairn hotel. The church has got a pipe organ and seems to be a great place of worship. The caretaker was great in inviting us to visit inside the church. Recommend this place to everyone if you are staying in Dickoya.
Touching testimonial to the hardships, the loneliness and perhaps some of the consolations of the Victorian plantation managers' lives.
Nice Place overlooking a Lake. Fine for sitting in the shadow of the trees with a look over the lanke and the teafields.

Place is quaint and serene. If I'm not mistaken its around two centuries old and still have the original structure. What I loved about the place is the sense of calmness and the beautiful view. Do pay a visit and talk to Mr. Felix ( caretaker) of the church for a full 360 about the place.

In the most picturesque of locations, over looking the reservoir, stands the beautiful Warleigh Church. Built by planters over a 150 years ago, it is the final resting place for many of the colonial residents from that time. A must see on your Hill country Tour
A place of religious interest - A 'must see' by all visitors travelling to or through Dickoya, Hatton

The Warleigh Church is a very beautiful old church built in the eighteenth century and in a very beautiful location earlier it would have overlooked the tea country of Sri Lanka now it overlooks the castlereigh reservoir .The ancient anglican cemetery is also well kept like the church  a place not to be missed when in Sri Lanka

We happened upon this enchanting place today on our way to our tea trail accommodation - I had mentioned to our guide that I wools like to see the inside of a church so as to compare with all the temples that we had seen. This pretty church dates from 1878 and is very well maintained both on the inside and also the graveyard. The caretaker's wife scurried out to unlock the church so as to show us the beautiful inside - a donation of 200 rupees was much appreciated. Very pleased to have found it.

It's a quaint little church that stands on a hill. In it's gardens rest some of the first Planters that settled in Sri Lanka from Britain. The very first bible gifted to the church by the  Methodist church in the 1800's still sits on the pulpit. Go there if you like traveling back in time.
We stopped off here on Christmas eve as we were in the area. The church warden opened up for us and pointed out the various features and toured the churchyard with us. A lovely place.

The church gifted by Englishman William Scot (1878) is built like a typical British church and stands on Wanarajah Estate near the hamlet of Dickoya. We were the only visitors on a cloudy day, but that didnt dampen the beauty of the tiny church. The original bible that was gifted to the church is still lovingly kept at the alter. It is a great place to find out about your ancestors, if they were posted in Sri Lanka during the time of the British! There is a large pipe organ at the back and a tiny organ in the front of the church. We spent more than 30min inside the premises (the church door was locked) and on our way out, the caretaker, who had been alerted by his wife, met us looking not too pleased! He made an excuse to open the church door, but we convinced him to! He went on about the fact that there are rogues in the area and that they are very careful who should come visit! His negative chatter distracted us, so much so that we couldnt ask whether there were any prominent people buried there! I wonder if the welcome would have been any different, if we were foreigners! Every other Sunday there is an English Service at 8am.
